breaking_news.title: China-linked APT UNC3886 breaches Singapore telcos using zero-days and rootkits
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: China-linked APT UNC3886 conducted a sustained cyber espionage campaign against all four major Singapore telecom providers—M1, SIMBA Telecom, Singtel, and StarHub—using zero-day exploits, rootkits, and custom backdoors. The Cyber Security Agency of Singapore (CSA) and Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) revealed the operation, codenamed Cyber Guardian, which spanned 11 months and involved sophisticated persistence mechanisms, log tampering, and exploitation of vulnerabilities in network devices and virtualization platforms.

Paragraph 2: The attack targeted critical national infrastructure with the intent of long-term intelligence gathering rather than disruption, raising serious concerns about supply chain compromise and national security. Although customer data and services remained unaffected, the intrusion into core telecom infrastructure demonstrates the growing capability of state-sponsored actors to operate undetected in highly monitored environments, setting a precedent for similar campaigns globally.

breaking_news.title: Critical BeyondTrust RCE flaw (CVE-2026-1731, CVSS 9.9) actively exploited pre-auth
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: BeyondTrust disclosed and patched a critical pre-authentication remote code execution vulnerability (CVE-2026-1731, CVSS 9.9) in its Remote Support (RS) and older Privileged Remote Access (PRA) products. The flaw allows unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary OS commands via specially crafted HTTP requests, granting full system control. The vulnerability was disclosed on February 6, 2026, and patches were released immediately, but evidence suggests active exploitation prior to patching.

Paragraph 2: Given the widespread use of BeyondTrust tools in enterprise environments for privileged access management, exploitation could enable attackers to escalate privileges, move laterally, and compromise high-value assets—including domain controllers and cloud infrastructure. The severity and pre-auth nature make this a top-priority patch for organizations relying on BeyondTrust solutions for security operations.
affected_entities: Global enterprise customers using Remote Support and PRA

breaking_news.title: ZeroDayRAT spyware kit available on Telegram enables full iOS/Android compromise
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: A new commercial mobile spyware platform named ZeroDayRAT is being marketed on Telegram as a turnkey surveillance toolkit capable of full remote control over compromised Android and iOS devices—including screen mirroring, microphone and camera access, message interception, location tracking, and app manipulation. Researchers confirm it rivals nation-state-grade capabilities, with modular architecture and anti-analysis features designed to evade detection.

Paragraph 2: Unlike traditional mobile malware, ZeroDayRAT is sold commercially to cybercriminals, significantly lowering the barrier to sophisticated mobile espionage. Its availability threatens high-value targets such as executives, journalists, activists, and government personnel, and could enable large-scale credential theft, corporate espionage, and identity fraud across consumer and BYOD environments.

breaking_news.title: Warlock ransomware breaches SmarterTools via unpatched SmarterMail (CVE-2025-26399)
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: The Warlock ransomware group (also known as Storm-2603) exploited an unpatched SmarterMail server to breach SmarterTools’ internal network on January 29, 2026. The attack leveraged a known vulnerability in SmarterMail (CVE-2025-26399), which had been added to CISA’s KEV catalog but remained unpatched at SmarterTools. The attackers deployed ransomware, exfiltrated data, and disrupted internal operations—though business applications and customer data were not impacted.

Paragraph 2: This incident exemplifies the persistent risk of unpatched, high-severity vulnerabilities in widely used enterprise software, especially when exploited by ransomware groups with rapid operational tempo. SmarterTools’ compromise of its own email platform underscores the need for rigorous patch management discipline and segmentation of critical infrastructure—even within software vendors themselves.

breaking_news.title: SolarWinds WHD exploited in multi-stage attacks to deploy Velociraptor and Zoho tools
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Threat actors are actively exploiting multiple vulnerabilities in SolarWinds Web Help Desk (WHD), including CVE-2025-40551 (deserialization RCE) and CVE-2025-26399, to gain initial access and deploy post-exploitation tools like Velociraptor and Zoho ManageEngine for persistence and remote control. Huntress confirmed active exploitation as of February 7, 2026, with attackers mapping networks and lateral movement via compromised WHD instances.

Paragraph 2: These attacks demonstrate the shift toward leveraging legitimate tools (e.g., Velociraptor) to evade detection and maintain access, blurring the line between offensive security tools and malicious infrastructure. Organizations running unpatched SolarWinds WHD instances are at severe risk, especially those with exposed internet-facing systems—a common configuration oversight that attackers routinely abuse.

breaking_news.title: European Commission confirms mobile device management breach exposing staff data
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: The European Commission disclosed a cyberattack on its central mobile device management (MDM) platform, detected on January 30, 2026. Attackers potentially accessed staff names, phone numbers, and email addresses, though no mobile devices themselves were compromised. CERT-EU contained and cleaned the system within nine hours, but the breach highlights weaknesses in MDM infrastructure—a high-value target for intelligence gathering against EU institutions.

Paragraph 2: As the executive arm of the EU, the Commission handles sensitive policy, diplomatic, and financial data; a breach of its MDM system could enable future credential theft, AitM attacks, and targeted phishing against high-ranking officials. The incident reinforces the urgent need for zero-trust architecture and continuous monitoring of identity and access management systems across critical public institutions.

breaking_news.title: DKnife AitM toolkit hijacks routers since 2019 to intercept traffic and deliver malware
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Cisco Talos uncovered DKnife, a China-linked gateway-monitoring and adversary-in-the-middle (AitM) framework active since at least 2019. The toolkit consists of seven Linux-based implants that hijack router traffic via deep-packet inspection, manipulate software downloads and Android app updates, and deliver backdoors like ShadowPad and DarkNimbus—primarily targeting Chinese-speaking users.

Paragraph 2: DKnife’s longevity and stealth (C2 infrastructure still active as of January 2026) illustrate the enduring threat posed by persistent, infrastructure-level espionage tools. By compromising edge devices, attackers gain long-term access to encrypted traffic, credentials, and user behavior—bypassing endpoint security entirely. This underscores the critical need for supply chain integrity and continuous monitoring of network infrastructure devices.
affected_entities: Enterprise networks with exposed edge devices

breaking_news.title: Critical Fortinet FortiClientEMS SQLi (CVE-2026-21643, CVSS 9.1) enables unauthenticated RCE
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Fortinet patched a critical SQL injection vulnerability (CVE-2026-21643, CVSS 9.1) in FortiClientEMS that allows unauthenticated remote code execution via crafted HTTP requests. The flaw, discovered internally, could enable attackers to gain initial access, deploy malware, and pivot into internal networks—especially dangerous given FortiClientEMS’s role in managing endpoint security policies across enterprises.

Paragraph 2: With widespread deployment in global enterprises and government agencies, unpatched FortiClientEMS instances represent high-value targets for APTs and ransomware groups. The vulnerability’s unauthenticated nature and high severity demand immediate patching or network segmentation—delaying remediation risks full network compromise through a single entry point.

unique_affected_entities: Enterprise networks with exposed edge devices
Global enterprise customers using Remote Support and PRA
